results.title: Zoo
results.creator_credit: Gerry Hudson, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: This film explores a wide variety of animals on display at the Melbourne Zoo. All the major different animal groups are represented and each animal is shown in a natural environment. Gives a close look to animals we would not normally see at close range.

results.title: Successful staff selection: the employment interview
results.brief_description: An illustration of how the manager prepares for, and handles, an interview to assess a candidate for a particular job. Job specifications, unobtrusive control of the form of the interview, handling stress on the candidate, etc. are related to a full length simulated interview for a job.

results.title: Art, people, feelings
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford, Paul Burnford Film Productions and Pyramid Films
results.brief_description: The relationship between human emotions and the art created is illustrated by a selection of artistic works which span all periods of history and a variety of subjects. Shows ways in which artists use many materials and methods to translate their personal feelings into visual forms: murals, landscapes, portraits, posters, billboards, abstract paintings, cartoons, pop art, sculpture and motion pictures. Suitable for secondary level years 7-12.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Burnford, Paul Burnford Film Productions and Pyramid Films

results.title: Buffalo: an ecological success story
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Describes the physical traits of the North American buffalo and its natural habitat, its struggle for survival from the time vast herds ranged across the continent through the mass slaughters of the 1800’s, and the measures taken to save the buffalo from extinction. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Atomic structure and correlations within the Periodic Table
results.creator_credit: David G. Anderson, Andrew Patterson, Jr and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: The first episode of this film looks at atomic structure and the Periodic Table, and the second episoe looks at correlations with the Periodic Table. Using a blackboard size Periodic Table from which individual elements can be removed or placed at will, this film illustrates a method of using the Periodic system to determine the electronic structure of atoms. Suitable for Upper-Secondary students.

results.title: They can do it
results.creator_credit: Lore Rasmussen, Allan Leitman and Education Development Centre
results.brief_description: Traces the development of an infant teacher’s approach to a class over a period of eight months at Pastorious Public School, Philadelphia. Initial traditional methods gain little response from her negro and underprivileged students. On introduction of a more relaxed and individual teaching program, the children become more involved with their surroundings and teacher.

results.title: Medbourne Primary School
results.creator_credit: Henry Felt and Education Development Center
results.brief_description: Focuses mainly on the seven to eleven year-olds and the teachers in a rural school in which the total enrolment is forty-eight. Shot over a period of five days, the film shows the continual activity. Some children are painting, others are using their printing press, while others are cooking a chicken outside.

results.title: Wild Africa: the energy cycle
results.creator_credit: James Murray, William Banting and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: This film discusses the flow of energy from green plants through the herbivores and carnivores of the African plains. Various herbivores are shown eating and these in turn are food for carnivores. Concentrates on the flow of food energy. Taken from the orginal production entitled ‘Wild Africa: as it was’.

results.title: What sex is your job?
results.brief_description: Looks at the characteristics of women’s work in three different areas where it is seen to be tedious, badly paid or involves physical stress. In each section there is a point being made about the underlying discrimination against women.
results.description: Looks at the characteristics of women’s work in three different areas where it is seen to be tedious, badly paid or involves physical stress. In each section there is a point being made about the underlying discrimination against women.

results.title: What did you do in the Great War Mummy?
results.brief_description: This film shows that there have traditionally been two labour markets in Britain based on the concepts of “mens” work and “women’s work”. Traces the history of women workers in the twentieth century with emphasis on the roles they played during the two world wars. These national emergencies shaped the change in attitudes regarding women and work, and during those conflicts, “a woman’s place” was no longer just in the home.
